description: From Middle English blinnen, from Old English blinnan (“to stop, cease”), from Proto-Germanic *bilinnaną (“to turn aside, swerve from”), from Proto-Indo-European *ley-, *leya- (“to deflect, turn away, vanish, slip”); equivalent to be- +‎ lin. Cognate with Old High German bilinnan (“to yield, stop, forlet, give away”), Old Norse linna (Swedish dialectal linna, “to pause, rest”). See also lin.

verbs.description: blin (third-person singular simple present blins, present participle blinning, simple past blinned or blan, past participle blinned or blun)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, especially Scotland, Northumbria, Yorkshire) To cease (from); to stop; to desist, to let up.
examples: One while the little foot page went, / And another while he ran; / Until he came to his journey's end / The little foot page never blan.
